item.label: Dorsal median sulcus
item.name: Dorsal median sulcus
item.description: The dorsal median sulcus or fissure of the spinal cord demarcates the dorsal midline point of the spinal cord.  It divides the dorsal columns into two halves and extends the length of the spinal cord.

item.label: Dorsal median septum
item.name: Dorsal median septum
item.description: The dorsal median septum of the spinal cord separates the two halves of the dorsal columns.  Specifically, it is located between the paired gracile fasciculi.  It is aligned with the dorsal median fissure.

item.label: Dorsal lateral sulcus
item.name: Dorsal lateral sulcus
item.description: The dorsal lateral sulcus of the spinal cord is where the dorsal roots enter the spinal cord. It extends the length of the spinal cord.

item.label: Vental lateral sulcus
item.name: Vental lateral sulcus
item.description: The ventral lateral sulcus of the spinal cord is AKA the anterolateral sulcus. It is a poorly defined sulcus marked by the exit of the ventral roots of the spinal cord. This sulcus extends rostrally into the medulla where it separates the pyramid from the olive. The rootlets of the hypoglossal nerve emerge from this sulcus in the medulla.

item.label: Ventral median fissure
item.name: Ventral median fissure
item.description: The ventral median fissure of the spinal cord is AKA the anterior median fissure. It is a deep fissure separating the two ventral or anterior columns of the spinal cord. This fissure extends into the medulla and stops at the caudal aspect of the pons. It is interrupted by pyramidal decussation at the junction of the spinal cord with the medulla.

item.label: Dorsal root (rootlets)
item.name: Dorsal root (rootlets)
item.description: A dorsal root is AKA a posterior or sensory root of the spinal cord. It contains the axons of sensory neurons whose cell bodies are located in the ipsilateral dorsal root ganglion (or sensory ganglion) on the respective spinal nerve.  As the nerve fibers leave the ganglion, they break up into multiple divisions known as rootlets and enter the spinal cord at the dorsal lateral sulcus. These axons terminate within the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Ventral root (rootlets)
item.name: Ventral root (rootlets)
item.description: Ventral roots of the spinal cord contain the axons of lower motor neurons whose cell bodies are located in motor regions of the spinal cord. Those axons originating in the ventral or anterior horns will terminate on skeletal muscles, while those originating in the lateral horns will terminate on post-ganglionic neurons in autonomic ganglia. Upon exiting the spinal cord and prior to joining the dorsal root to form the spinal nerve, the roots are subdivided into rootlets.

item.label: White matter
item.name: White matter
item.description: The white matter of the spinal cord contains the myelinated and unmyelinated axons that travel up and down the neuraxis.  It consists of named tracts or pathways such as the spinothalamic and corticospinal tracts.

item.label: Dorsal column
item.name: Dorsal column
item.description: The dorsal column or funiculus is AKA the posterior column or funiculus. It is that portion of the white matter of the spinal cord that is located between the dorsal median sulcus/septum and the dorsal lateral sulcus, i.e. the point of entry of the dorsal roots. Present bilaterally, each side includes two sub-parts, the fasciculus gracilis (located medially, closest to the midline; at all levels of the spinal cord; carries input from the lower extremity and body) and the fasciculus cuneatus (located laterally, closest to the dorsal root entry; present only above approximately T6; carries input from the upper extremity and body). The dorsal columns are composed of ascending tracts that carry tactile (discriminative touch), vibratory and proprioceptive sensory input.

item.label: Lissauer's tract
item.name: Lissauer's tract
item.description: Lissauer's tract is AKA the dorsolateral fasciculus.  It is an area of spinal cord white matter located between the dorsal tip of the dorsal horn and the surface of the spinal cord. It consists of unmyelinated and thinly myelinated primary afferent axons from the lateral division of the dorsal root. These axons carry pain and temperature information and will synapse in the ipsilateral dorsal horn within a few cord segments.

item.label: Lateral column
item.name: Lateral column
item.description: The lateral column or funiculus of the spinal cord is that portion of the white matter that is located between the dorsal lateral sulcus (point of entry of the dorsal roots) and the ventral lateral sulcus (point of exit of the ventral roots). Present bilaterally, it contains both ascending and descending tracts including the clinically important corticospinal tract and part of the spinothalamic tract.

item.label: Ventral column
item.name: Ventral column
item.description: The ventral columns or funiculi of the spinal cord are AKA the anterior columns or funiculi of spinal cord. They are the part of the white matter of the spinal cord that extends from the ventral (or anterior) median fissure to the ventral lateral sulcus, i.e. the point of exit of the ventral roots from the spinal cord. Present bilaterally, it contains several tracts, most of which originate at higher levels of the neuraxis. However, part of the clinically important spinothalamic tract is located in this funiculus.

item.label: Gray matter
item.name: Gray matter
item.description: The gray matter of the spinal cord contains the neuropil of the spinal cord: nerve cell bodies, dendrites, axon terminals & synapses.  It is divided into the paired dorsal or posterior horns, paired ventral or anterior horns, paired intermediate gray areas, and the central gray matter that surrounds the central canal.  This gray matter is further subdivided by cytoarchitecture and function into the Rexed's laminae.

item.label: Central gray
item.name: Central gray
item.description: The central gray is that region of the spinal cord gray matter that surrounds the central canal.

item.label: Dorsal horn
item.name: Dorsal horn
item.description: The dorsal horn of the spinal cord is AKA the posterior horn of the spinal cord. It is that portion of spinal cord gray matter dorsal to the central canal that generally deals with sensory information. Since it is a derivative of the alar plate, it deals with sensory functions.

item.label: Intermediate gray
item.name: Intermediate gray
item.description: The intermediate gray matter is that region of spinal cord gray matter between the dorsal (posterior) and ventral (anterior) horns.  It has characteristics of both dorsal and ventral horns and contains the preganglionic autonomic neurons as well as the Clark's nucleus (nucleus dorsalis).

item.label: Ventral horn
item.name: Ventral horn
item.description: The ventral horn of the spinal cord is AKA the anterior horn of the spinal cord. It is a major division of the spinal cord gray matter that contains the lower motor neurons (AKA anterior horn cells) that innervate the skeletal muscles of the body. These lower motor neurons include alpha motor neurons that innervate extrafusal muscle fibers and gamma motor neurons that innervate the intrafusal fibers of the muscle spindles.  At the level of the lumbar and cervical enlargements, the lateral aspect of the ventral horn is enlarged and contains the lower motor neurons innervating the limbs.  This area is known as the lateral motor cell column.  The more medial aspect of the ventral horn contains the lower motor neurons innervating axial structures; it is known as the medial motor cell column and is present at all levels of the spinal cord.

item.label: Lateral motor cell column
item.name: Lateral motor cell column
item.description: The lateral motor cell column of the spinal cord is part of the gray matter of the ventral or anterior horn of the spinal cord at cervical and lumbar levels.  It is located laterally in the ventral horn and contains those lower motor neurons that innervate the extremities.

item.label: Medial motor cell column
item.name: Medial motor cell column
item.description: The medial motor cell column of the spinal cord is part of the gray matter of the ventral or anterior horn of the spinal cord at all levels of the spinal cord.  It is located medially in the ventral horn and contains those lower motor neurons that innervate axial structures.

item.label: Substantia gelatinosa
item.name: Substantia gelatinosa
item.description: Substantia gelatinosa is the area of gray matter at the dorsal aspect of the dorsal or posterior horn at all levels of the spinal cord. It corresponds to Rexed's lamina II. It derives its name from freshly-sectioned spinal cord where it appears pale due to its relative lack of myelinated nerve fibers. In conjunction with Lissauer's tract, it deals with afferent pain and temperature information and the modulation of that input by the descending raphe spinal tract. Note that it becomes essentially continuous with the trigeminal spinal nucleus in the transition from spinal cord to medulla.

item.label: Corticospinal tract, lateral
item.name: Corticospinal tract, lateral
item.description: The lateral corticospinal tract is a descending pathway (of Upper Motor Neurons) that originates in the cerebral cortex, travels through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, basis pedunculi of the midbrain, basilar pons, the pyramid of the medulla and then decussates at the medulla/spinal cord junction. The tract then travels in the lateral funiculus of the spinal cord with its fibers terminating along the length of the cord on both motor and sensory neurons. Its fibers and their cells of origin are considered to be Upper Motor Neurons. This is the primary pathway that deals with skilled voluntary movements.

item.label: Lissauer's tract
item.name: Lissauer's tract_1
item.description: Lissauer's tract is AKA the dorsolateral fasciculus.  It is an area of spinal cord white matter located between the dorsal tip of the dorsal horn and the surface of the spinal cord. It consists of unmyelinated and thinly myelinated primary afferent axons from the lateral division of the dorsal root. These axons carry pain and temperature information and will synapse in the ipsilateral dorsal horn within a few cord segments.

item.label: Gracile fasciculus
item.name: Gracile fasciculus
item.description: The gracile fasciculus is part of the dorsal or posterior column of white matter along the entire length of the spinal cord. It includes large, uncrossed, primary afferent fibers carrying tactile, vibratory and proprioceptive input from the lower extremity and the body below approximately T6.  While most of these fibers will terminate in the gracile nuclei in the caudal medulla, a substantial portion will terminate in Clark's nucleus (nucleus dorsalis) in the lumbar and lower thoracic aspect of the spinal cord.  Note that in upper thoracic and cervical cord segments, the dorsal column includes a more laterally located fiber bundle, the cuneate fasciculus.  The fibers in the cuneate fasciculus carry the same modalities of sensation from the upper extremity and the body above approximately T6.

item.label: Reticulospinal tract
item.name: Reticulospinal tract
item.description: The reticular formation gives origin to multiple descending tracts known as reticulospinal tracts. Originating primarily in the medullary and pontine reticular formation, these tracts have several functions. They relay information from the hypothalamus to the preganglionic neurons at lower levels; thus a lesion of the reticulospinal tract in the lower medulla or spinal cord can produce Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the central control of the sympathetic innervation to the head. These descending tracts also have a major impact on motor control, especially the level of reflex activity that imparts muscle tone and core postural mechanisms; the balance of excitation and inhibition that they impart on lower motor neurons is upset when thes tracts are damaged, leading to hyperactive reflexes and increases in muscle tone. Finally, the raphe spinal tract that is associated with blocking pain at the dorsal horn, is often considered to be part of the reticulospinal tracts.

item.label: Spinothalamic tract
item.name: Spinothalamic tract
item.description: The spinothalamic tract is primarily responsible for transmitting nociceptive (pain) and temperature information from the body. Small diameter primary afferents (first order neurons) bring the pain and temperature information into the ipsilateral dorsal horn where they synapse on the cells of origin of the spinothalamic tract. The second order neurons in the dorsal horn send their axons across the midline in the ventral white commissure so that the spinothalmamic tract ascends in the anterolateral portion of the spinal cord contralateral to the side of input of the information. This tract terminates in the ventral posterior lateral nucleus (VPL) of thalamus. From this thalamic nucleus, the information is carried to the primary somatosensory cerebral cortex where the sensation is consciously perceived.

item.label: Spinocerebellar tract, ventral
item.name: Spinocerebellar tract, ventral
item.description: The ventral or anterior spinocerebellar tract carries proprioceptive information from neurons in the dorsal aspect of the ventral horn in the thoracic-lumbar spinal cord to the ipsilateral cerebellum. The tract decussates in the ventral white commissure near its origin and is then located in the ventral-lateral aspect of the lateral column of the spinal cord, contralateral to the side of input. This tract takes a circuitous route to cerebellum via the superior cerebellum peduncle and recrosses the midline within the white matter of the cerebellum so that it terminates ipsilateral to the original side of input. The information in this tract comes from proprioceptors in the ipsilateral lower extremity that send their input via large diameter primary afferents to terminate or synapse in the dorsal aspect of the ventral horn.

item.label: Vestibulospinal tract
item.name: Vestibulospinal tract
item.description: The vestibulospinal tract (AKA the lateral vestibulospinal tract) originates in the vestibular nuclei at the pons/medulla junction and terminates on motor neurons in the spinal cord. Since the vestibular nuclei receive input from the cerebellum, this tract in an important (indirect) route whereby the cerebellum can influence spinal cord motor neurons.  Do not confuse with the medial vestibulospinal tract (AKA the medial longitudinal fasciculus).

item.label: Anterior spinal artery
item.name: Anterior spinal artery
item.description: The anterior spinal artery originates as a branch from each of the vertebral arteries at the level of the medulla; these branches then join to form a single vessel which travels caudally in the ventral median fissure of the spinal cord. Along with tributaries from the radicular arteries, it supplies the anterior 2/3rds of the spinal cord.
